section.p: The configuration file, /etc/default/serviced, is a systemd-compliant text file that contains environment variables. The serviced daemon startup script, /etc/systemd/system/multi-user.target.wants/serviced.service, reads /etc/default/serviced to load the parameters and initial settings of the service. The startup script defines a few environment variables, but the values defined in /etc/default/serviced take precedence over the values defined in the script.
The following list describes the variables in /etc/default/serviced.

dlentry.dd: The path Docker clients use to locate the .dockercfg authentication file. Docker Hub credentials are stored in the file.
The path serviced uses to spool snapshots and images during backups.
The maximum number of CPU cores serviced uses.

Determines whether a serviced instance performs delegate tasks. Delegate run application services scheduled for the resource pool to which they belong. The serviced instance configured as the master runs the scheduler. A serviced instance may be configured as delegate and master or just delegate.

Determines whether a serviced instance performs master tasks. The master runs the application services scheduler and other internal services, including the server for the browser interface. A serviced instance may be configured as delegate and master or just delegate. Only one serviced instance in a cluster may be the master.
The list of endpoints in the serviced ZooKeeper ensemble, separated by the comma character (,). Each endpoint includes the IP address and port of an ensemble node.
The serviced master host is always a node in the serviced ZooKeeper ensemble. For single-host deployments, {{SERVICED_MASTER_IP}} does not need to be replaced.
The IP address and port number of the serviced Docker registry host. Replace {{SERVICED_MASTER_IP}} with the IP address of the serviced master host.

The outbound IP address to set when is used in a private network. Setting the Docker HTTP_PROXY or HTTPS_PROXY environment variables prevents access to the serviced outbound IP address. To enable access, unset the variables, and then reboot the host.
A list of one or more static IP addresses reserved for serviced to use when it advertises external IP addresses on behalf of services it manages. Use the comma character (,) to separate addresses.
The IP address and port number of the serviced RPC endpoint. Replace {{SERVICED_MASTER_IP}} with the IP address of the serviced master host.
The port number of this endpoint must match the value of the SERVICED_RPC_PORT variable on the serviced master host.

The maximum number of connections the serviced RPC endpoint supports. The value is used to create a pool of sockets, which are reused as needed. Increasing the value increases the number of open sockets and the use of socket-related operating system resources.
The port on which a serviced master listens for RPC connections. The value of this variable must match the port number of the SERVICED_ENDPOINT variable on serviced delegates.
Determines whether serviced performs TLS certificate verification for RPC connections.
Determines whether serviced uses TLS for RPC connections.

The list TLS ciphers serviced supports for RPC connections:
TLS_ECDHE_RSA_WITH_AES_128_CBC_SHA
TLS_RSA_WITH_AES_128_CBC_SHA
TLS_RSA_WITH_AES_256_CBC_SHA
TLS_ECDHE_RSA_WITH_AES_256_CBC_SHA
TLS_ECDHE_RSA_WITH_AES_128_GCM_SHA256 To disable support for a cipher, remove it from the list.

The port on which the HTTP server on the master host listens for requests from browser interface clients. The value may be expressed as follows:
IP-Address:Port-Number
:Port-Number
Port-Number
Versions 1.0.x and 1.1.x: If the default value is changed, the colon character (:) must precede the port number.
The number of seconds between polls from browser interface clients.
The port serviced uses for communications among Docker containers on its private subnet.
Determines whether TLS is used for inter-host communications among Docker containers. Intra-host communications among Docker containers is not encrypted. To disable TLS, set the value to 1.

The list TLS ciphers serviced supports for mux communications:
TLS_ECDHE_RSA_WITH_AES_128_GCM_SHA256
TLS_ECDHE_ECDSA_WITH_AES_128_GCM_SHA256
TLS_ECDHE_RSA_WITH_AES_256_CBC_SHA
TLS_ECDHE_RSA_WITH_AES_128_CBC_SHA
TLS_ECDHE_RSA_WITH_3DES_EDE_CBC_SHA
TLS_ECDHE_ECDSA_WITH_AES_256_CBC_SHA
TLS_ECDHE_ECDSA_WITH_AES_128_CBC_SHA
TLS_RSA_WITH_AES_256_CBC_SHA
TLS_RSA_WITH_AES_128_CBC_SHA
TLS_RSA_WITH_3DES_EDE_CBC_SHA To disable support for a cipher, remove it from the list.
DEPRECATED. Use SERVICED_ISVCS_PATH, SERVICED_VOLUMES_PATH, and SERVICED_BACKUPS_PATH instead.
The location of serviced internal services data.
The location of serviced application data.
The location of serviced backup files.
The path of a TLS key file. The default, insecure key file is created when the serviced web server first starts, from a public key that is compiled into serviced.

The path of a TLS certificate file. The default, insecure certificate file is created when the serviced web server first starts, from a public certificate that is compiled into serviced. Certificates with passphrases are not supported.
The minimum version of TLS serviced accepts. This setting extends to the applications serviced manages. Valid values include the default, VersionTLS11, and VersionTLS12.

The list TLS ciphers serviced that accepts:
TLS_ECDHE_RSA_WITH_AES_128_GCM_SHA256
TLS_ECDHE_ECDSA_WITH_AES_128_CBC_SHA
TLS_ECDHE_RSA_WITH_AES_256_CBC_SHA
TLS_ECDHE_ECDSA_WITH_AES_256_CBC_SHA
TLS_RSA_WITH_AES_256_CBC_SHA
TLS_ECDHE_ECDSA_WITH_AES_128_GCM_SHA256
TLS_ECDHE_RSA_WITH_AES_128_CBC_SHA
TLS_RSA_WITH_AES_128_CBC_SHA
TLS_ECDHE_RSA_WITH_3DES_EDE_CBC_SHA
TLS_RSA_WITH_3DES_EDE_CBC_SHA To disable support for a cipher, remove it from the list.
The driver to manage application data storage on the serviced master host. Valid values are rsync, btrfs, and devicemapper.
Only devicemapper is supported in production deployments. The btrfs type is deprecated and the rsync type is appropriate only in development deployments.

The recommended storage layout for the devicemapper driver is a device mapper thin pool. To create and resize a thin pool, use the serviced-storage utility. To specify the name of the thin pool device, use the SERVICED_DM_THINPOOLDEV variable.
The name of the thin pool device to use with the devicemapper storage driver.
Determines whether loop-back files can be used with the devicemapper storage driver. This option is not supported for production use.
The list of virtual host aliases to use in virtual host multiplexing, separated by the comma character (,).
The number of seconds serviced waits before removing a stopped container.

The 16-bit private subnet to use for serviced's virtual IPv4 addresses. RFC 1918 restricts private networks to the 10.0/24, 172.16/20, and 192.168/16 address spaces. However, serviced accepts any valid, 16-bit, IPv4 address space for its private network, in CIDR notation.

The relative amount of INFO messages serviced writes to the system log. Valid values are 0 (minimum) to 5 (maximum). If persistent log storage is enabled, the log file is /var/log/journal/serviced.log. Otherwise, log data is stored in a ring buffer.
The logstash endpoint to which log data are sent. Replace {{SERVICED_MASTER_IP}} with the IP address of the serviced master host.
The endpoint of the logstash service. Replace {{SERVICED_MASTER_IP}} with the IP address of the serviced master host.
The maximum number of days to keep data in the logstash server before purging it. When both this variable and SERVICED_LOGSTASH_MAX_SIZE are set, both conditions are evaluated and enforced.
The maximum amount of logstash data to keep, in gigabytes. When both this variable and SERVICED_LOGSTASH_MAX_DAYS are set, both conditions are evaluated and enforced.
The amount of time between logstash purge cycles, in hours.
The endpoint of the OpenTSDB reader daemon for serviced statistics. Replace {{SERVICED_MASTER_IP}} with the IP address of the serviced master host.
The number of seconds between polls (health checks) of serviced cluster hosts.
The number of seconds to cache statistics of running services for browser interface clients.
The port on which serviced listens for HTTP requests for the Go profiler. To stop listening for requests, set the value to -1.

dd.p: Arguments to pass to internal services. You may define multiple arguments, each for a different internal service. The variables themselves, and their arguments, use the following syntax:

dlentry.dd: Each variable name ends with a unique integer in place of %d.

dd.p: The value of each variable includes the following elements, in order:

ol.li: Service-Name, the internal service name. The following command returns the internal service names that may be used for Service-Name: docker ps | awk '/serviced-isvcs:/{print $NF}'
Key, a variable to pass to the internal service.
Value, the definition of the variable to pass to the internal service.

dd.p: The following example variable passes ES_JAVA_OPTS=-Xmx4g to the Elasticsearch internal service.

dlentry.dd: The name of the Linux group on the serviced master host whose members are authorized to use the serviced browser interface. You may replace the default group with a group that does not have superuser privileges.
Determines whether root, or members of the wheel group, may gain access to the serviced browser interface.

The default value of this variable ensures that a serviced delegate does not run out of connections if the serviced master goes down. In testing this scenario, the connection count on delegates running a nominal number of collector services does not exceed 10,000 closed connections. The connections are automatically cleaned up by the kernel soon after the serviced master comes back online.

The number of hours an application data snapshot is retained before removal. To disable snapshot removal, set the value to zero. The application data storage can fill up rapidly when this value is zero or too high.
The number of seconds a serviced delegate waits to update its /opt/serviced/var/monitor/IP-Address file.
The number of seconds between polls of device mapper kernel statistics about the application data thin pool.

The interval, in seconds, at which the serviced master checks the modification times of the /opt/serviced/var/monitor/IP-Address files of active delegates. The value of this variable must be a minimum of twice the value of the SERVICED_MONITOR_DFS_REMOTE_UPDATE_INTERVAL variable.
Determines whether the serviced master restarts NFS when it detects active delegates that are out of synchronization.
Determines whether a serviced delegate mounts the DFS. To disable mounting, set the value to 0.
Overrides the default value for the service migration image.

Enables one or more internal services to run on a delegate host. The list of services:
celery
elasticsearch
logstach
opentsdb
docker-registry
zookeeper Currently, only zookeeper is supported.
The unique identifier (a positive integer) of a ZooKeeper ensemble node.

The comma-separated list of nodes in a ZooKeeper ensemble. Each entry in the list specifies the ZooKeeper ID, IP address, peer communications port, and leader communications port of a node in the ensemble. Each quorum definition must be unique, so the IP address of the "current" host must be 0.0.0.0. IP addresses are required; hostnames are not supported.
The following example shows the syntax of a node entry: ZooKeeper-ID@IP-Address:2888:3888

The log driver for all Docker container logs, including containers for internal services. Valid values:
json-file
syslog
journald
gelf
fluentd
none This is a direct port of the Docker --log-driver option.

A comma-separated list of Docker --log-opt options as key=value pairs. To specify the default values for a log driver, or for drivers that need no additional options, such as journald, use a single comma character (,) as the value of this variable.
Special options for the serviced startup command.

The relative amount of the tenant volume that contains application data, expressed as a percentage the total size. This value is used to determine whether the volume has enough free space to hold a new snapshot.
The number of seconds before a ZooKeeper ensemble node times out a connection attempt.
